results.abstract: The Orlando massacre resonated across the world not as an American anomaly, but because it felt so universal.

results.abstract: The Moscow Patriarchate’s decision highlighted tensions between the Russian branch and a rival leadership based in Istanbul.

results.title: Oscar Pistorius Is Unfit to Testify at Sentencing, Psychologist Says
results.abstract: A defense psychologist argued that Mr. Pistorius should be hospitalized rather than imprisoned: “His condition is severe.”

results.title: South Sudanese Suffer as Leaders Dispute the Nature of Their Home
results.abstract: A fragile peace deal could bring traders back to Terekeka after South Sudan’s civil war. But first, the formerly warring parties must agree on what Terekeka is: a county or a state.

multimedia.caption: A family of farmers in Terekeka, South Sudan, said the cost of living had increased as a result of the country’s civil war, which killed tens of thousands of people and displaced more than two million.

results.abstract: The woman was prosecuted on charges of adultery and alcohol consumption and received a one-year suspended sentence.

results.title: How China Won the Keys to Disney’s Magic Kingdom
results.abstract: Plans for the $5.5 billion Shanghai Disney Resort, which opens Thursday, were in limbo until Disney dialed back its demands to the Communist Party.
results.byline: By DAVID BARBOZA and BROOKS BARNES

results.title: Afghanistan and Pakistan Exchange Heavy Gunfire Along Border
results.abstract: The fighting, which forced the closing of the Torkham crossing, left at least 13 wounded in Pakistan and killed least one Afghan police officer.
results.byline: By ISMAIL KHAN and ROD NORDLAND

results.title: Australian Rodent Is First Mammal to Go Extinct Due to Climate Change, Scientists Say
results.abstract: In 2014, researchers used traps and cameras to try to determine how many Bramble Cay melomys were left on a tiny outcrop in the Great Barrier Reef. They found none.

results.title: Smithsonian to Open London Exhibition Space With Victoria and Albert Museum
results.abstract: The institution’s first permanent outpost abroad will be part of a complex in the east of the city called Olympicopolis, due to open in 2021.

results.title: Incendiary Memoir by Chinese Rights Lawyer Reaches Bookshelves Abroad
results.abstract: In the book, the lawyer, Gao Zhisheng, describes his time as a prisoner from 2009 to 2014, when he was released and sent to live under police surveillance.

results.title: Reports Tell of a Trail of Migrant Deaths Across Deserts and Seas
results.abstract: Millions of migrants have fled war and poverty in their homelands. But two reports on Tuesday highlighted the perils they face as they seek refuge in other countries.
des_facet: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

multimedia.caption: Crew members of the Norwegian tanker Clipper Hebe moving a coffin containing the body of a migrant at the port of Augusta in Sicily this month. A report released on Tuesday said that thousands of migrants had died trying to cross seas and deserts.

results.abstract: Reports of fighting and possible deaths — and the lack of solid information — raise fears that Ethiopia and Eritrea are sliding once more into war.

results.title: Search Is On for King Henry I, Who May Be Buried Under a Parking Lot
results.abstract: Nearly four years after archaeologists discovered King Richard III’s grave under a parking lot, experts are hoping to find the remains of Henry under another one.

results.title: China’s Call to Young Men: Your Nation Needs Your Sperm
results.abstract: With sperm banks facing shortages, a government campaign tries to overcome cultural barriers to donation with appeals to patriotism (and some cash).

results.title: Could Long-Lost Amber Room Be Stashed in a Nazi Bunker in Poland?
results.abstract: A museum in the country’s northeast says it has evidence of a hidden chamber inside a compound used by German forces, and that it may contain the treasure lost during World War II.
